COVID-19 is spread from person-to-person via respiratory droplets such as coughs and sneezes.
These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or be inhaled into the lungs.
Neither surfaces nor animals can carry the disease by themselves.

COVID-19 is spread from person-to-person via respiratory droplets such as coughs and sneezes.
These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or be inhaled into the lungs. 
Neither surfaces nor animals can carry the disease by themselves.

patterns: how does coronavirus spread in my town
responses:
Community spread is when people have been infected in an area, including those who are unaware they were infected.
These individuals allow the virus to spread easily and sustainably in the community (hence community spread).

patterns: will coronavirus end in the summer
is coronavirus back in the winter
is it safe in the summer
responses:
Infectious experts are unsure if weather will affect the spread of COVID-19. Other viruses, like those that
cause the common cold and flu, tend to spread more during colder seasons. This does not mean it is 
impossible to contract the virus in other months.

The CDC has no data to suggest that COVID-19 is spread by mosquitoes, ticks, other bugs, or other non-human
life. The main way that COVID-19 spreads is from person to person.

patterns: why is the cdc doing nothing
responses: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) is working with other federal partners in a whole-of-government response. This is an emerging, rapidly evolving situation and CDC will continue to provide updated information as it becomes available. CDC works 24/7 to protect peopleâ€™s health.

patterns: how can i protect my family
how can i protect my child
responses:
Wash your hands often, avoid close contact with others, cover your face with a mask when around others, 
cover coughs and sneezes, and disinfect surfaces frequently. Always be alert for possible symptoms!

Although the virus can survive for a short period on some surfaces, COVID-19 is  thought to be spread most often
by respiratory droplets. It is unlikely to be spread from domestic or international mail, products or packaging.

Community mitigation activities are actions that people and communities can take to slow the spread of COVID-19, such as washing hands, disinfecting surfaces, practicing social distancing, wearing face coverings around others, and covering coughs and sneezes.

patterns: is it safe to donate blood
responses: The CDC encourages people who are well to continue to donate blood if they are able to.

Currently there is no evidence to suggest contact lens wearers are more at risk for acquiring COVID-19
than eyeglass wearers, or vice versa.

patterns: how long do i wash my hands
is soap better than hand sanitizer
can i use hand sanitizer over soap and water
responses:
Handwashing is one of the best ways to protect yourself and your family from getting sick. Wash your hands
with soap for at least 20 seconds after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing; going to the bathroom; and
before eating or preparing food. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer

Disinfect frequently touched surfaces such as tables, doorknobs, light switches, countertops, handles, 
desks, phones, keyboards, toilets, faucets, and sinks. Visit the CDC website for cleaning guidelines.

patterns: what do i do if i have covid
how long does it take to recover
responses:
Most people who get COVID-19 will be able to recover at home. Quarantine in isolation for fourteen days
and wear a face mask when around family members.

patterns: is my kid at high risk
responses:
Children are not as high risk for COVID-19, although some children and infants have been sick with COVID-19.
If you believe your child may have COVID-19, consult your healthcare provider immediately.

patterns: Are the symptoms of COVID-19 different in children than in adults
do different people have different symptoms
responses:
Symptoms of COVID-19 are similar for all people who contract it, although symptoms can look different in
different people.

patterns: should my child wear a face mask
should my son wear a face mask
responses:
Everyone two years and older should wear a face mask. Cloth face coverings should NOT be put on babies
or children younger than 2 because of the danger of suffocation.

This is a condition where different body parts can become inflamed. Children who have COVID-19
may also contract this. Consult your healthcare provider if you believe your child may have this.

patterns: can my teen hang out with friends
can my kid go on a playdate
can i go out with friends
responses:
The key to slowing the spread of COVID-19 is to practice social distancing. Going out and socializing is
extremely dangerous during a global pandemic. Please stay safe and away from others.

patterns: how do i feed my child
will my child continue getting food at school
responses: Check with your school on plans to continue meal services during the school dismissal.

patterns: how do i make hand sanitizer
responses:
CDC does not encourage the production and use of homemade hand sanitizer products because of
concerns over the correct use of the ingredients.

patterns: what are the symptoms of covid19
responses:
People with these symptoms may have COVID-19:
Fever or chills
Cough
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Fatigue
Muscle or body aches
Headache
New loss of taste or smell
Sore throat
Congestion or runny nose
Nausea or vomiting
Diarrhea
Notify your healthcare provider if you believe you or someone you know has COVID-19.
Not everyone needs to be tested for COVID-19. If you have symptoms, call your healthcare provider first.

If you think you need a viral or antibody test, call your healthcare provider first. Your healthcare provider may
have these tests at his/her office. If not, contact your local health department and they may have tests available.

patterns: what are the different kind of tests
what are the different type of tests
responses: Viral tests are used to diagnose COVID-19 and antibody tests are used to see if you already had COVID-19.

patterns: if i recovered from coronavirus, am i immune
responses:
The CDC is unsure if people who recover from COVID-19 can get infected again. Continue to take steps to
protect yourself and others.

patterns: is my husband at high risk
responses:
Those 65 and older or with underlying medical conditions are at higher risk of severe illness from COVID-19.
If you are at higher risk, follow CDC protection guidelines and stay home as much as possible.

Contact tracing involves identifying people who have COVID-19 and their contacts and working with them
to interrupt disease transmission.

patterns: does my dog cat have coronavirus
responses: Animals do not play a role in COVID-19 transmission. Tests and vaccines are not widely available for animals.

patterns: can i swim in a pool
responses: COVID-19 has not been detected in treated drinking water, pools, or open bodies of water.
